articles.headline: Health Law Tax Penalty? I’ll Take It, Millions Say
articles.snippet: A lot of healthy people are defying predictions by the Affordable Care Act architects and refusing to enroll, throwing off the math behind the system.
articles.abstract: A lot of healthy people are defying predictions by the Affordable Care Act architects and refusing to enroll, throwing off the math behind the system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The architects of the Affordable Care Act thought they had a blunt instrument to force people — even young and healthy ones — to buy insurance through the law’s online marketplaces: a tax penalty for those who remain uninsured.

articles.headline: Megyn Kelly’s Pivotal Moment in a Post-Ailes Era at Fox News
articles.snippet: The host’s divergent approach took a different turn in her clash with Newt Gingrich and again raised the question of the channel’s future.
articles.abstract: The host’s divergent approach took a different turn in her clash with Newt Gingrich and again raised the question of the channel’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early last year, in an article in The New York Times Magazine, I defined what I called a “Megyn moment,” in a profile of the Fox News host Megyn Kelly:

articles.headline: Individualized Ads on TV Could Be One Result of AT&T-Time Warner Merger
articles.snippet: In a call with investors, the chiefs of the companies noted that the combined trove of their consumer data would be useful to marketers and consumers.
articles.abstract: In a call with investors, the chiefs of the companies noted that the combined trove of their consumer data would be useful to marketers and consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Targeting people with individualized TV commercials using cable or satellite boxes has been promoted as the future of television for at least a decade. But the business, known as addressable TV advertising, has remained on the fringes, usually limited to two minutes of local commercial time an hour on cable shows.

articles.headline: An Annuity for the Teacher — and the Broker
articles.snippet: A look inside the high-pressure job of selling workplace annuities to public schoolteachers.
articles.abstract: A look inside the high-pressure job of selling workplace annuities to public schoolteachers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bradley Bergeron’s first professional job out of college was selling retirement savings investments to public schoolteachers in Connecticut. The applications he carried in his black leather briefcase, however, were for one type of product only: a high-priced variable annuity.

articles.headline: Buying at a Used Car Auction? What You Don’t Know Could Kill You
articles.snippet: Consumers are able to purchase cars that have deadly defects and sellers have few obligations to disclose the defects to them.
articles.abstract: Consumers are able to purchase cars that have deadly defects and sellers have few obligations to disclose the defects to them.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, two reporters from The New York Times visited a car auction held in Queens by the New York City Department of Finance.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Used Cars Slip Past Recall Safeguards, Putting Drivers in Danger
articles.snippet: Federal law does not mandate used-car sellers to tell buyers when a car has been recalled or to make necessary safety repairs, and the results can be deadly.
articles.abstract: Federal law does not mandate used-car sellers to tell buyers when a car has been recalled or to make necessary safety repairs, and the results can be deadly.
articles.lead_paragraph: The outdoor lot of Mr. Z Towing in Flushing, Queens, looked like an automotive graveyard.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Donations to Foundation Vexed Hillary Clinton’s Aides, Emails Show
articles.snippet: A new release by WikiLeaks reveals how efforts to limit potential conflicts led to infighting among advisers in the years before Mrs. Clinton announced her 2016 candidacy.
articles.abstract: A new release by WikiLeaks reveals how efforts to limit potential conflicts led to infighting among advisers in the years before Mrs. Clinton announced her 2016 candidacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the years before Hillary Clinton announced she would run again for president, her top aides expressed profound concerns in internal emails about how foreign donations to the Clinton Foundation and Bill Clinton’s own moneymaking ventures would affect Mrs. Clinton’s political future.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Jail Time for Using South Africa’s Worst Racial Slur?
articles.snippet: A South African woman is on trial after a racist tirade was caught on video, and lawmakers are moving to make hate speech a crime punishable by imprisonment.
articles.abstract: A South African woman is on trial after a racist tirade was caught on video, and lawmakers are moving to make hate speech a crime punishable by imprisonment.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — After thieves broke into her car, a white South African motorist lashed out at the responding black police officers. She called black people “plain and simple useless” before unleashing the most offensive racial slur around.

articles.headline: Some Donald Trump Voters Warn of Revolution if Hillary Clinton Wins
articles.snippet: Among Mr. Trump’s supporters, some worry that they will be forgotten, along with their concerns, if Mrs. Clinton wins. Others predict violent conflict.
articles.abstract: Among Mr. Trump’s supporters, some worry that they will be forgotten, along with their concerns, if Mrs. Clinton wins. Others predict violent conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Big crowds still mob Donald J. Trump when he comes to town, with fans waiting in long lines to attend his rallies, where they eagerly jeer his Democratic rival and holler happily at his message.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Will the Next President Face a Recession? Don’t Assume So
articles.snippet: You can’t predict a recession based on the length of an expansion; it doesn’t work that way.
articles.abstract: You can’t predict a recession based on the length of an expansion; it doesn’t work that way.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic expansion that has been underway in the United States since 2009 is getting old, and soon will die.

articles.headline: Twitter to Cut Jobs as It Aims for a Turnaround
articles.snippet: The social media company said it would lay off 9 percent of its work force, as it reported an increase in users and a narrowing of losses.
articles.abstract: The social media company said it would lay off 9 percent of its work force, as it reported an increase in users and a narrowing of losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For months, the question facing Twitter has been what its fate will be.

articles.headline: Broadband Providers Will Need Permission to Collect Private Data
articles.snippet: The new rules require broadband providers to get permission to collect data on a subscriber’s web browsing, app use, location and financial information.
articles.abstract: The new rules require broadband providers to get permission to collect data on a subscriber’s web browsing, app use, location and financial information.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal officials approved broad new privacy rules on Thursday that prevent companies like AT&T and Comcast from collecting and giving out digital information about individuals — such as the websites they visited and the apps they used — in a move that creates landmark protections for internet users.
